description: Distinguish deductively valid arguments from formal fallacies
prompts:
"Some football fans admire various clubs, others love only a single team. But who is a fan of whom precisely? The following argument pertains to this question: First premise: Mario is a friend of FK Žalgiris Vilnius. Second premise: Being a follower of F.C. Copenhagen is necessary for being a friend of FK Žalgiris Vilnius. It follows that Mario is a follower of F.C. Copenhagen."
 Is the argument, given the explicitly stated premises, deductively valid or invalid?

"Is Fred a cousin of Robert? Is Joe related to Bob? In large families, it is sometimes difficult to keep track of all one's relatives. The following argument seeks to clarify some such relations: To start with, Tom is a half-brother of Charles. Now, everyone who is a half-brother of Charles is a close friend of Armando, too. We may conclude: Tom is a close friend of Armando."
 Is the argument, given the explicitly stated premises, deductively valid or invalid?

"It is not always easy to see who is related to whom -- and in which ways. The following argument pertains to this question: First, everyone who is a stepsister of Ann is a great-grandmother of Elsie, too. Second, Deanna is a stepsister of Ann. Hence, Deanna is a great-grandmother of Elsie."
 Is the argument, given the explicitly stated premises, deductively valid or invalid?

"It is not always easy to see who is related to whom -- and in which ways. The following argument pertains to this question: First of all, Marvin is a schoolmate of Louis. Next, being a schoolmate of Terrence is necessary for being a schoolmate of Louis. All this entails that Marvin is a schoolmate of Terrence."
 Is the argument, given the explicitly stated premises, deductively valid or invalid?

"Here comes a perfectly valid argument: First premise: Adolfo is a great-grandfather of Timothy. Second premise: Being a great-grandfather of Timothy is sufficient for being a classmate of Andres. From this follows: Adolfo is a classmate of Andres."
 Is the argument, given the explicitly stated premises, deductively valid or invalid?

"Is Titanium oxide an ingredient of my washing power? Which chemicals does my perfume contain? It is really difficult to keep track of all chemicals one is regularly exposed to. The following argument seeks to clarify some such relations: First premise: Vitamin A palmitate is an ingredient of Shampoo Rinse Free. Second premise: Every ingredient of Shampoo Rinse Free is an ingredient of My Yacht, My Rules!. We may conclude: Vitamin A palmitate is an ingredient of My Yacht, My Rules!."
 Is the argument, given the explicitly stated premises, deductively valid or invalid?

"Is Titanium oxide an ingredient of my washing power? Which chemicals does my perfume contain? It is really difficult to keep track of all chemicals one is regularly exposed to. The following argument seeks to clarify some such relations: Retinol palmitate is an ingredient of Kickin' Curves. Everything that is an ingredient of Kickin' Curves is an ingredient of 02 Body & Leg Shine, too. So, necessarily, Retinol palmitate is an ingredient of 02 Body & Leg Shine."
 Is the argument, given the explicitly stated premises, deductively valid or invalid?

"It is not always easy to see who is related to whom -- and in which ways. The following argument pertains to this question: First, being a schoolmate of Janel is sufficient for being a workmate of Wanda. Second, Debra is a schoolmate of Janel. Hence, Debra is a workmate of Wanda."
 Is the argument, given the explicitly stated premises, deductively valid or invalid?

"It is not always easy to grasp who is consuming which products. The following argument pertains to this question: First, Matilda is an infrequent user of Lush soap. Second, being an owner of a Herbal Essences shampoo is necessary for being an infrequent user of Lush soap. It follows that Matilda is an owner of a Herbal Essences shampoo."
 Is the argument, given the explicitly stated premises, deductively valid or invalid?

"Is Siri a stepsister of Mary? Is Susan related to Kate? In large families, it is sometimes difficult to keep track of all one's relatives. The following argument seeks to clarify some such relations: First of all, Sheila is a workmate of Jessica. Next, being a workmate of Jessica is sufficient for being a workmate of Beatriz. Hence, Sheila is a workmate of Beatriz."
 Is the argument, given the explicitly stated premises, deductively valid or invalid?

 Is the argument, given the explicitly stated premises, deductively valid or invalid?
